question: Should private universities in the UK be encouraged?

content.source_1: Department for Business, Innovation & Skills (2016) — “Success as a Knowledge Economy: Teaching Excellence, Social Mobility and Student Choice” (White Paper). Argues for lowering barriers to entry for high‑quality new (including private) providers, granting routes to degree‑awarding powers and university title to drive competition, innovation, and student choice.
content.source_2: National Audit Office (2014) — “Financial support for students at alternative higher education providers.” Finds rapid growth in publicly funded students at private/alternative providers accompanied by weak oversight, high dropout rates at some institutions, and risks of abuse of student loan funding; recommends tighter controls and regulation.
content.source_3: BIS / IFF Research (2016) — “Alternative Providers of Higher Education: The Students.” Reports that alternative (often private) providers disproportionately serve mature, working, and Black and minority ethnic students, offering flexible and vocational courses; evidence that the sub‑sector can support widening participation and different learner needs.
content.source_4: House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee (2018) — “Treating Students Fairly: The Economics of Post‑School Education.” Concludes the HE “market” shows weak price competition, with most universities charging the maximum fee; cautions that increasing the number of providers alone is unlikely to lower prices or deliver market‑style efficiencies.
content.source_5: BBC News (2019) — “GSM London to close, leaving thousands of students affected.” Documents the collapse of a private higher education provider and the disruption to students, underscoring student‑protection and continuity risks when private institutions fail.
content.source_6: Department for Education & Department for International Trade (2019, updated 2021) — “International Education Strategy: Global potential, global growth.” Sets targets to grow international student numbers and education exports, encouraging a competitive, diverse provider base to meet global demand; implies private universities can expand capacity and specialist provision.
